posts.name:
Yash Kumar
Yash Kumar
posts.content:
“ You need to be SHAMELESS! “ 

said the $1000,000 Sales legend Matt Lakajev. Here’s what I learnt: 

↳ Most people think lead gen is icky.

↳ They think it’s icky, because deep down they are scared

↳ They are scared, because they think people will judge them.

You don’t get clients for two reasons:

1️⃣ You are not doing enough:

→ Throw shame out of the window.

→ Start 30 conversations daily.

2️⃣ You are not good enough:

→ Don’t be too quick. Build a real connection.

→ Have a “ Micro Offer “ before you sell.

BONUS TIP:

Genuinely,is so humble, and was so helpful during the call.

And that’s what gets you in the “ 1%” of sales legends.

Next Post: How the “ Micro Offer Strategy “ can transform your sales?

Repost, so your network can be in the “ 1% Club ” too! ️

posts.content: This is your permission slip to be YOU. You've always been you, but this is a reminder: people connect with the real, not the fake. Embrace your quirks and share your story. Do YOU give yourself permission?

comments.commentText: Love this message of self-acceptance, Goldie.

posts.name:
Brad Voorhees
Brad Voorhees
posts.content:
I've seen it happen too many times.

Leadership teams gather for their offsite meetings, armed with financial reports and marketing strategies.

But when it comes to discussing their real challenges – the people issues – silence fills the room.

The CFO shifts uncomfortably in their chair.
The CMO stares at their laptop.
No one wants to address the elephant in the room.

This is where having an HR Advisor makes all the difference.

Here's what typically happens without one:

→ Teams avoid discussing critical people issues
→ Performance problems persist unaddressed
→ Culture challenges compound over time
→ Employee engagement drops
→ Top talent starts leaving

The cost of waiting is substantial.

Here's what changes with an HR Advisor at the leadership level:

1. Strategic People Planning:
They bring data-driven insights about workforce trends, succession planning, and talent development.

2. Proactive Problem Solving:
Issues get addressed before they become crises.

3. Cultural Intelligence:
They provide actionable strategies for building and maintaining company culture.

4. Executive Partnership:
They speak the language of business while translating complex people issues into strategic initiatives.

5. Risk Management:
They help navigate complex employment laws and regulations before problems arise.

Consider this real scenario:

A fast-growing tech company waited until they hit 250 employees before bringing in senior HR leadership.

→ Leadership was spending 60% of their time on people issues
→ Their compensation structure was inconsistent
→ They had no succession plans
→ Employee turnover was rising

Within 6 months of working with me:

- Employee satisfaction improved
- Clear people strategies were in place
- The executive team could focus on growth
- Leadership meetings became more productive

The best part?

The leadership team finally had someone who could translate people challenges into business opportunities.

So if you're sitting in leadership meetings avoiding the real issues, maybe it's time to consider bringing in an HR Advisor before it's too late.

comments.commentText:
Brad Voorhees that’s because the people issues take a ton of time and energy to develop, align and implement 

And most executives would just rather focus on the sales and profits

When, in fact, if they invested in the people, then the profits would take care of themselves
